=Examples of Darwin Core as RDF using Darwin-SW object properties=

*Date:* (Created) 27 June 2013; (Last modified) 30 June 2013

*Status:* Not part of any standard ([http://www.tdwg.org/fileadmin/tdwg_std_drafts/tdwg_standards_documentation_specification.html#a_3 Type 3] document); intended to complement the RDF Guide of the Darwin Core Standard ([http://www.tdwg.org/standards/450/])

*Permanent URL:* http://

*TDWG Task Group:* [http://code.google.com/p/tdwg-rdf/ TDWG RDF/OWL Task Group]

*Contributors:* [mailto:steve.baskauf@vanderbilt.edu?subject=RDFguide Steve Baskauf] (TDWG RDF/OWL Task Group)

*Abstract:* These examples follow the Darwin Core RDF Guide. They assume the data model of Darwin-SW (version 0.3; http://code.google.com/p/darwin-sw/ ) and use its object properties to link the class instances.  See http://code.google.com/p/tdwg-rdf/wiki/BiodiversityOntologies for a comparison of some data models that provide object terms that can be used with Darwin Core.

== 2 Complex example ==

This is a complex example based on a real situation where several images and a specimen were collected to document a seed collection.  It uses terms from Darwin Core and the draft Audubon Core for multimedia metadata.  The resource URIs are real except for the specimen and the identification associated with it (a specimen was collected, but it's metadata are not yet available.)

In this example, two events are linked to a single location.  There are two occurrences (one associated with each event).  One occurrence is documented by a single image.  A later occurrence is documented by both a specimen and an image.  The IndividualOrganism instance is a small population of plants, documented by the occurrences and from which the images and specimen were derived.  The population has two Identification instances.  One is based on the two images while the other is based on the specimen.  Each image has four ServiceAccessPoints from which size variants can be acquired. Although there are only several resources involved, it demonstrates how RDF can describe complex situations in a highly normalized way.

<img src="http://tdwg-rdf.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/file/images-obj-pro-only.png" height="200" width="3855"/>

[http://tdwg-rdf.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/file/images-obj-pro-only.jpg Click here to view image in your default viewer]
